bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Camilo Chavez, April 28, 1948

div1.p: Hench requests enlargements of the aerial photographs which Chavez obtained. He would also like to borrow the negatives.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Camilo Chavez, April 28, 1948
div1.opener:
April 28, 1948
Colonel Camilo Chavez
Cuban Army Air Force
Ciudad Militar
Marianao, Cuba
My dear Colonel Chavez:
div1.p:
I wondered if you could do me a very real favor. In Washington, May
10 to 15, will be held an International Congress on Tropical Medicine under the
auspices of the United States Government. Many distinguished visitors will be
present. I have been asked to give an address on the conquest of yellow fever
the evening of May 12. I have also been asked to set up an exhibit on the con-
quest of yellow fever. In connection with this, I am most anxious to have some
large photographs of the air views which you and your colleagues so kindly made
for me. Would it be possible for me to ask for two things.
1. Could your department prepare for me a set of enlargements of the
air views which you took for me. I think there were five or six in the air map
from LaPlaya to the Hippodrome and then there were the two excellent photographs
(the second ones taken, the tangential views of the Finca San Jose and the re-
mains of Camp Lazear). The one was especially fine as it showed the military
hospital of Ciudad Militar and LaPlaya in the background. I should be very
glad to pay for these enlargements. I hesitate greatly to ask your department
to make these but I do not believe any local organization has the facilities
for enlarging them like the large views you gave me. Certainly the photographic
department of the Mayo Clinic cannot do it. Otherwise, I would merely ask you
to lend us the films and I would have it done here.
2. Could you also lend me for a short time, the negatives or films
of these views. I should like to have quite a few additional prints made to
help me in my campaign to arouse interest among American physicians in the
preservation of Camp Lazear. I have tried to make a photographic copy of one
of the prints you sent me and it isn't bad but it isn't nearly as clear as
the originals.

Is there any possibility that I could receive these enlargements and
prints by May 10 or 11. I will be arriving at the Hotel Mayflower in Washing-
ton, D. C., and if you could air mail them to me I shall be very glad to pay
the expense. It could be marked as follows: Dr. Philip S. Hench, Hotel
Mayflower, Washington, D. C., “Hold for arrival, May 11”. I should like very
much to exhibit some of these prints in Washington at the International Congress
to show them where the work of Doctors Finlay and Reed and their colleagues was
done.

If you will let me know much this is I will send you my personal
check promptly. Let me express again my sincere appreciation for the wonder-
ful help you have given me in obtaining these views. They are quite invaluable.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P. S.: If it is impossible for you to have the enlargements made, if you
will send me the negatives I will do the best I can here to have them en-
larged properly.
